nodes.bodyText: Unnecessary cast to InternalCacheEntry and should be MarshallableEntry<?, ?>

the cast is necessary for some weird reason that I fail to understand.
If you don't cast, java will invoke org.infinispan.persistence.spi.MarshallableEntryFactory#create(java.lang.Object)
Unnecessary cast to InternalCacheEntry
Unnecessary whitespace

This won't be compatible with a 10.1.x SingleFileStore. To keep the FileEntry compatible, we could alter the MAGIC array to determine which version we're reading from.
For example:
private static final byte[] MAGIC_10.1.x = new byte[]{'F', 'C', 'S', '1'};
private static final byte[] MAGIC = new byte[]{'F', 'C', 'S', '2'};
We then pass boolean readInternalMetadata to rebuildIndex() and handle accordingly.
Obviously we would need a test with the 10.1.x bytes to ensure this works correctly.
\cc @wburns

I agree the MAGIC should be changed... but does it need to be backward compatible?
isn't that the StoreMigrator's job?
The StoreMigrator is a get out of jail, not quite for free, card. The long term goal is to get so that we can do rolling upgrades seamlessly in kubernetes, so we need to avoid any manual steps.

oh... that was unexpected...
SingleFileStore can be fixed but the remaining stores (RocksDB, JDBC, SIFS, JPA) are probably broken. there is no "magic" or "version" field there :/
@pruivo we can relatively easy add a new column family for metadata in RocksDB, and a metadata table in JDBC/JPA. For SIFS we may need a breaking change.

My bad, I was only thinking about the missing magic/version fields, so was using "metadata" as "information about the store itself", not as in "information about the entries".
I'm not very familiar with JPA either, but for JDBC/RocksDB it should be fairly easy to check when opening a store if the new table/column family exists or not.
However, this doesn't completely solve our problem, we also have to migrate the existing entries, or we wouldn't be able to change the version of the store, and we wouldn't be able to store the internal metadata.

@pruivo @danberindei  For store implementations that use MarshalledValueImpl to store the value, i.e. Jdbc & Rocksdb, we should be ok because you have added the internal metadata there. The way Protobuf/ProtoStream works, if a field is missing from the old bytes, then it just isn't read and so in MarshalledValueImpl we can just set the internal metadata to null. So there shouldn't be any additional logic in the store itself AFAICT.

About JPA, my knowledge is -infinity. I just copy what others did

That's what we all do 😆
Nitpick, but can we inline like elsewhere.
JPA is still a dark art to me. Will this have any impact on backwards compatibility? Or will the new field simply not be set if it does not exist?
Why is this change necessary?
no, but catching an exception just to throw it, is a waste of bytecodes :P

Like the SFS this won't be backwards compatible as the HEADER_SIZE has changed, however in this case we can't workaround this using the MAGIC array as it does not exist. So I think we might need to add a magic field, and read accordingly depending on whether it is/isn't present.
I would prefer adding the version information as a separate file, so we can easily check if the version information exists and default to the 10.1 layout (or migrate in-place to the 11+ layout).
A separate file makes sense.
Don't forget 🙂

nodes.bodyText: HEADER_SIZE_10_1 and HEADER_SIZE_11_0 would be more informative.
ack

I would prefer to avoid writing MAGIC per header if possilbe. However, if we can't avoid that we should at least store it as a single byte. useMagic was only ever used for testing, so we don't have to worry about the compatibility of this field as it was never used in production.

I'll change to byte.
IMO, it is better to keep a magic number per entry. If I understand correctly, SIFS only appends the keys changes to a new file; So, if the format changes in the future, we don't need any migration during startup.
What if the user is migrating a store from the existing version of Infinispan, i.e. 11.x?

no sure If I understand what you mean... migrating for 11.0 to 11.x?
The filenames changed with this PR and the FileProvider only searches for old file names, i.e. the file names previous to this PR.
After this PR, the users don't need to migrate anything. We have the magic number per entry so we are able to read anything.

no sure If I understand what you mean... migrating for 11.0 to 11.x?

Yes. Currently it's possible to migrate from one store implementation to another, e.g. SIFS -> RocksDB, within the latest Infinispan version.
You can determine the version of the source store via StoreProperties#getMajorVersion and call readOldEntryHeader if < 11

ok!
I wasn't aware of that. I need to update SFS too since it is only parsing the old format.

nodes.bodyText: name attribute is redundant as the proto name will already be "internalMetadata"
I don't think these static methods simplify things. arrayLength and bufferLenth are only called once as well. I would prefer just to keep the checks inline.
I think this log and a message indicating that the migration has sucessfully completed should be info the same as in SFS.
should the log message be in the class logger or under PERSISTENCE logger?
Good question. I think PERSISTENCE. The same applies for SFS
Nitpick. Single line comment
Why is this necessary? Can't we just use tmpDirectory(Class<?> test)?

This is for the JPA store.
The path has to be set in persistence.xml but the tmpDirectory() method uses infinispan.test.tmpdir. If infinispan.test.tmpdir is not set, it falls back to java.io.tmpdir.
If I use infinispan.test.tmpdir and it was not set, the DB will point to the incorrect location.

Can be:
return ByteBufferImpl.create(b, offset, length);`
there is no ByteBufferImpl.create(b, offset, length); method. Are you suggesting creating one?

Sorry, I was thinking there was. But yeah lets add ByteBufferImpl.create(b, offset, length), that way all of the logic around EMPTY_INSTANCE is in one place and ByteBufferImpl.create(b) impl can just call the overloaded method.

done!
I changed PersistenceMarshallerImpl a little since it was allocating and copying the array twice.
Good spot, thanks
Nitpick. Unnecessary empty line
We can pass this to the constructor of PersistenceCompatibilityTest so that we don't have to override setup and teardown in all of the tests.

We can set the Global persistent location here:
builder.globalState().persistentLocation(CommonsTestingUtil.tmpDirectory())
That way not all of the tests have to override amendGlobalConfigurationBuilder and it should not negatively effect the JPA and JDBC tests that don't need it.
It would be good to have the prefix values as constants, e.g. 10_1_PREFIX = "", 11_0_PREFIX="ispn."
We should use the statements you introduced in Log.java
The code will be a lot cleaner if we statically import PERSISTENCE log.
